message: For the Python in Finance panel on Wednesday afternoon, we'd like to get some questions from attendees.  Please post questions here on anything even remotely related to the use of Python in quantitative finance, trading, banking, etc.
Please update on numpy native datetime project.
OK, I will ask about that.
Thanks Mark and Warren.  My followup question is about being able to see an example of this concept used for *arrays* of business days.  Maybe the datetime sprint is a better place for this, though.

Regarding Travis's question about numpy datetime, do you know if business days are going to be supported?  It is nice to have Friday + 1 = Monday in those contexts for example, without having to worry about masks, etc.
maybe stuff there can be recycled for provisioning private cloud
Tutorial material: check out https://github.com/scipy-lectures. If it is useful, fork it, submit patches.
Yes, I see how it works now
Hmm.  This is nontrivial.  I think I will get Mateusz to do it. :)
Aaron: if you want to contribute that material to the sympy chapter (originally written by Fabian) you are welcome.
Come to my Dexy talk (11:40 am) tomorrow to learn how to write an easily updatable scipy book ;-)
@jseabold I will pose this question when we discuss institutional challenges later.
yes please put the tutorial link here...
Any plans for community organizing and more advertizing? Something like R-sig-finance ML or R/Finance conference for pushing Python. Both for support and development discussions. Too soon?
Gael, our tutorial is already on GitHub (https://github.com/mattpap/scipy-2011-tutorial).  I don't know if you just want to fork it from that user or what.
